facts.text: Appellant was employed as a clerk in the office of the District Relief and Rehabilitation Office, Meerut.
Malekchand applied for allotment of a house.
Appellant accepted Rs. 20/- as illegal gratification from Malekchand with a view to getting a house allotted to Malekchand.
Investigation conducted by a police officer below the rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police, in contravention of Prevention of Corruption Act.
There was an enquiry before commitment to the Sessions; no objection raised during commitment proceedings that investigation was by officer below DSP rank.
Case committed to Court of Session before Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 came into force.
Case tried by Assistant Sessions Judge.
Appellant convicted under s. 5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act and s. 161 IPC, sentenced to one year's rigorous imprisonment on each count, sentences to run concurrently.
Appellant appealed to Additional Sessions Judge (Criminal Appeal No. 225 of 1953), judgment dated August 6, 1953.
Allahabad High Court Criminal Revision No. 1403 of 1953, judgment dated December 16, 1955.
Appellant's defence: Took Rs. 20 from Malekchand to purchase wheat for him.
Malekchand's evidence: Paid Rs. 20 to appellant on demand to secure house allotment.

legal_issues.text: Whether investigation by police officer below rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police vitiates the conviction under Prevention of Corruption Act.
Whether Assistant Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to try the case, or it was triable only by Special Judge under Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952.
Whether courts below correctly appreciated nature, extent and quantum of proof required for raising presumption under s. 4 of Prevention of Corruption Act.
Whether sentence of one year's rigorous imprisonment is unduly severe.

petitioner_arguments.text: Investigation by police officer below DSP rank contravened Prevention of Corruption Act, vitiating conviction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Prevention of Corruption Act; H.N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. State of Delhi

petitioner_arguments.text: Assistant Sessions Judge had no jurisdiction as case triable only by Special Judge.
Courts below did not correctly appreciate proof required for presumption under s.4 Prevention of Corruption Act.
Sentence should be considered leniently as incident in 1951 and appellant on bail.

court_reasoning.text: H.N. Rishbud decision does not support vitiation of conviction; no objection raised at early stage before trial court or commitment; point not raised before High Court; conviction not vitiated generally by non-compliance in investigation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Objection not taken at sufficiently early stage; cannot be raised now.

court_reasoning.text: Case committed to Sessions before Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952; s.10 transfers only cases pending before Magistrates, not Sessions Court; Asgarali case confirms Sessions Court retains jurisdiction.
High Court did not raise presumption under s.4; concurrent finding of fact that Rs.20 was illegal gratification based on prosecution evidence; defence disbelieved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ample evidence, no presumption needed; no substance in point.

court_reasoning.text: Sentence of one year RI for corruption not unduly severe, despite 1951 incident and bail.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not desirable to send back to jail but sentence appropriate.

holdings.text: Conviction not vitiated by investigation irregularity where no early objection raised.
Sessions Court retains jurisdiction for cases pending there at commencement of Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952.
Concurrent factual finding of guilt based on evidence, no presumption required.
Sentence of one year RI upheld.

precedents_cited.case_name: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Irregularity in investigation does not vitiate conviction unless objected early; court may order rectification if raised timely.

precedents_cited.case_name: Asgarali Nazarali Singaporewalla v. The State
precedents_cited.relevance: Cases pending in Sessions Court at commencement of Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 not transferred to Special Judge.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis of conviction and presumption argument; investigation requirements.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis of conviction for taking illegal gratification.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer of cases to Special Judge; does not apply to pending Sessions cases.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the conviction under s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act and s.161 IPC, and the concurrent sentences of one year rigorous imprisonment. Rejected all contentions on investigation, jurisdiction, proof, and sentence.

key_quotes.text: There can be no question that, on the facts found, the appellant was guilty both under s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act and under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The sentence of one years imprisonment for corruption by a public servant cannot, however, be considered as unduly severe.
key_quotes.speaker: court
